annotation.TEXT: Something else I'm not a big fan of? Falling objects combined with timed/moving platforms. I may dislike Crystal Man's stage a good bit for those falling crystals, but in the very least, you could take your time with them. Here? Not so much, especially once the Shadow Man platforms get thrown into the mix (mercifully though, it doesn't last that long).
From what I've seen, the Met-Trains seem to have a problem in that they'll only fire at you when you're to the right of them. Keep that in mind for the final portion of the next stage.

And here we have one of the main culprits for this video's length. Making a longer-than-usual Mega Man stage is a risky idea, and this serves as a good example as to what can go wrong with it. There is no good reason I can think of as to why this level needs to last as long as it does, especially when it's just an extension of a pre-existing stage that - for the most part - doesn't really offer anything interesting enough to actually spice up the overly long trek.
Also, a slide underneath a spike with one block of space to do so on either side. That situation right there is enough to dock a few points, at least in my view.

On that note, I realize having a few different checkpoints might get in the way of the central gimmick of this stage. Then again, the gimmick is something I'm not fond of either. Essentially, you need to travel to four different corners of a specific room to use certain special weapons on destructible walls, thereby opening the way to the final room. The process is long and downright frustrating the first time through, which is exactly why I'm not going to do it (you'll see what I mean towards the end).

The only real saving grace of this stage are a few shortcuts and some (unintentional) easy methods of getting around certain rooms. On that note, unless you like dying a lot, don't bother going through the guts lift room without Rush. The sea mines deal an unreasonably large amount of contact damage, and falling in the guts lift room is guaranteed to dump you into a gigantic pile of them below.

Following up my personal pick for the most boring stage in the game, we have what's probably my least favorite level in the game. Not exactly a good combo, and in relation to that, the start of this stage isn't very good either.

If Tier 1 was the "interestingly bad" zone, and Tier 2 was the "meh" zone, then Tier 3 is the "overstaying its welcome" zone. As if the length of this segment wasn't enough of an indication, a good portion of the levels in this tier just don't know when to stop. There are a few exceptions here and there, but overly long levels is basically the name of the game in this part.

Finishing off Tier 3 is the longest and arguably the most technical stage yet. Now then, I don't think mazes are an inherently bad idea; They just tend to get executed poorly. This one...sadly, isn't an exception to that, as far as I'm concerned. This level felt like a downright chore to get through the first time around, especially seeing as the start of the stage serves as the only checkpoint (aside from the boss corridor).

This isn't meant as an offense to Flashman85, but I honestly don't feel bad about doing that. If I had gone through the intended method of beating this stage, it would have tacked another 4 or so minutes onto an already overly long video. That, and this stage generally brings about uncomfortable memories of Skate-o-Rama (while this stage isn't nearly as bad as that particular mess of a puzzle, I still can't help but be reminded of it).

Some advice for those of you planning on playing this: Never, ever try to ride the top platforms (unless you're forced to). To say that they're glitchy is putting it lightly. You can easily get stuck in them with no way to get out (until the platform passes through you completely, in which case it'll often dump you into spikes or a bottomless pit). The only way to avoid this is either to constantly jump while on them, or use Rush Jet to bypass them.

This section, while an interesting idea, is greatly flawed due to the glitchy nature of the top platforms. According to one of the judges, those who submitted levels had to test their own stages first (in order to ensure their completion). That begs the question: If the one responsible for this stage did test their level, then why did they not replace the top platforms with something more stable?

Overly long stages? Puzzles? Rush Coil/Jet abuse? Yeah, this seems like a good place for Yoku Man to me. Interestingly enough, Yoku Man's fight is much more straight-forward than it was in Unlimited. The only things I don't like about him are the blocks he summons (since it's very easy to get stuck inside them, giving you no chance to dodge his next attack), and his own version of the Yoku Attack (because if that shadow clone gets on you, you're not getting it off without something like Metal Blades).

I haven't really brought this up yet, but now seems to be as good of a time as any: Rush Jet is incredibly finicky in this game. Even after attempted fixes, it still has the tendency to act up, and nowhere is that more prevalent than in this stage. If you try to summon Rush one section at a time (rather than just fly through the entire thing, as seen here), there's a very good chance Rush will teleport away just as you're about to jump on him.
This particular stage isn't too long, but it still manages to be annoying due to technical issues involving the usage of Rush Jet (along with a certain type of platform that gets used later on).
